summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, filed under seal, providing the government's anticipated order of witnesses for the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It lists numerous witnesses, many of whom are authorized to testify using pseudonyms or first names only.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; the letter is addressed to her and responds to her directive from a pretrial conference.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330); the document pertains to the witness order for her trial.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the letter.

connections.description: Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference
events.description: A court conference where Judge Nathan directed the government to provide its anticipated witness order for the upcoming trial.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government's witness list for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial includes numerous witnesses authorized to testify under pseudonyms (e.g., 'Jane', 'O') or first names only.
The document is filed under seal due to concerns about revealing witness identities, as many are testifying with protected identities.
The government notes the witness order is subject to change due to travel schedules, personal obligations, and trial pace.
The government reserves the right to call additional witnesses or not call some of the listed ones as the trial progresses.
